response.answer_text: Question : How do I get rid of a gaming addiction? Preamble : You can’t change somebody else. You can help if that person asks for it, but the effort must come from an internal motivation. We, as a community, do not agree on what is a gaming addiction or if it exists at all. It does not really matter. What is important right now, is your feeling that you are playing too much. You are conscious there’s a problem. It’s a sign of maturity and you are not afraid to reach out. I am proud of you ! The most common advice is to ask for help and find trustworthy people. It’s a good starting point, but nobody can “fix” you in your place. Of course, everybody is different, you must find a way that works for you. The following is my method, maybe you can draw some inspiration from it. Let’s get down to business [to defeat…], shall we ? Know yourself Isolate yourself in a calm place with paper and pencils. Breathe deeply three times. Feel the air filling your lungs. Take time to answer honestly. Why do you play ? Playing too much is usually a substitute for something else. What is missing in your life ? Do you feel lonely ? not heard ? without control on your own life ? Do you feel trapped in your own limits ? Do you feel the need to empty your mind ? Write it down, be precise, and keep that paper near you. You are not limited to writing : use some lists, drawing, colors, symbols, or everything that you are comfortable with. There may be a lot of emotions, accept the fact that they exist. But, this too shall pass. You are the master of your own life. Be the rock in the middle of the river, letting water flowing around you. Put some words on these emotions as well and write it next to the rest. Goals The next step is to give a more precise direction for your life. Make a life plan (How to Make a Life Plan) and find out what you want (and don’t want) in your life. Another example that worked for me : imagine your own funeral (while it’s a bit morbid, the exercise is real). Next to the coffin, there is a booklet describing you. “Here lies [your name]. He/she was …” How would you like for this to continue ? It’s okay to have a vague idea for your long-term objectives, but your short-term should be realist (SMART Goals – How to Make Your Goals Achievable). Review everything once in a while. You are your best friend Don’t forget that you are the person that will accompany you until the end, at least make this person interesting… Find hobbies. Go outside, try different activities, learn to do something. Bonus points if it involves other people, like team sports, choirs, tabletop rpg, board games, ... or use your hands to create/craft something (pottery, woodworking, metalworking, painting, origami, juggling…). Have a look at all the clubs around you. In my case, I like to tell stories and I’m a developer, so I took some lessons in game design (excellent yt series : Extra Credits: Season 1 - YouTube). As a side advantage, now I can’t play a game without analyzing what works and what doesn’t. Once I find all the major patterns of mechanics and gameplay, it feels repetitive (few hours per game) so I become bored and simply stop. Games and you Stopping entirely requires an iron will. I suppose you wouldn’t be reading this if you had this will. The problem is not the game, it’s your behavior with the game. Games should be leisure and pleasure activities. Let’s put some rules : Gaming only after homework and housework.Each time you start a game, be conscious that you play because you WANT it, not because of habit. It makes a difference.Do a break each hour, get up, do a few jumping-jack, abs and push-ups.Set an alarm 15 min before bed, and stop everything when it rings.Stop playing when you’re not having fun.Don’t forget to write down your progress in your calendar ! Setbacks You will have relapses. Let’s face it, someday it will come by rote, maybe from another cause : your SO dumped you, your favorite sport team lost a match, and you just want to empty your mind. The “unthinkable” happens. So after your setback, you “wake up” and regret your action. You can’t change the past, but you can do better. You are a beautiful and evolving human being. You are worthy of love. I have faith in your ability to get up after your fall. Without silence, how could you appreciate music in its entirety ? Your efforts to become better will shine more if you are aware that you will have setbacks. But even though you know it will happen, you continue to fight, you magnificent bastard. The key is to get up more times than you fall, and measure the growing time between setbacks. You are not alone. Thank you for reading.

I personally feel you can and should limit the amount of time children spends playing any kind of video game or other type of screen time. Also I personally feel parents could benefit from using a “when/then” policy with video games and screen time. Example: “When you have finished these listed responsibilities- (detailed and specific) then you can have one hour of screen time.” Examples of responsibilities: homework, clean room, daily chore, showers. You can even give bonus time by saying something like ”If you have completed those responsibilities then you may do any of these other bonus chores for extra time.” and list the extra chore in writing with the amount of extra time. Example: dishes 10 minutes, laundry 5 minutes, sweeping in the kitchen 5 minutes, taking out the trash 5 minutes, 20 minutes of reading 10. This only works if you are consistent with making sure the responsibilities are actually being met and then refusing to allow the reward when it's not until it is. AND that you pick chores your children are actually capable of doing and continue to reassess their ability by age. If these is new to your family try only one responsibility at a time. I also see no reason why a 16 year shouldn't have a higher level of responsibility than their 12 year old sibling, or their 8 sibling, or their 5 year old sibling for the same reward. (Have them consider aging a level up- the higher level you get in life the harder the boss battle) Same thing for differently abled children, or handicapped children, base chores on what they are capable of. Don't think they can't be responsible for anything because they don't have the same ablity as someone else. Find something they can be responsible for and allow them to be responsible. It's good for everyone. I also don't see a reason for people to shelter children from the connection between recreation and responsibilities at the younger ages. ”You can play when the work is done” and ”take care of what you have or you lose it.” make for an easier transaction into adulthood. Which is the goal right? Adults with more responsible at work make more money, people with money have better luxuries. If adults choose to stop working, or working as well, they're choosing to give up the luxuries they already have. Start that thought process young and it won't be such a shocker. Most kids I see with video game addictions have inconsistent rules around video games. Very few actually have a true addiction, or truly addictive personalities or behaviors. However if you do have consistent rules around games and still feel your child has an addiction to it you can and should always get help from a pediatric therapist. Your regular doctor can refer you. Most insurance cover them. They can also help you build better reward system or goal setting than some random idiot online who has never met you or your kid- like me (random idiot right here). I do hope you find the best information to help you and your child.

I believe video games are actually a force for good in the world. Addiction, not so much. When I sold my PS3 to focus on other things, I eventually bought a PS4. That didn’t work. I moved from New Jersey to New York, started a whole new life. Games became apart of that. Moving away didn’t work. I tried a 90-day detox. On day 4 or something I picked the controller back up and played even more than I did before. That didn’t work. I joined a community of well-to-do people and it was awesome while it lasted. I had a falling out with the “leader” of that community and decided I couldn’t be apart of the group anymore, for my own integrity’s sake. Back to video games. That didn’t work. Not for good anyway. The only thing that worked for me was facing it head on. I stopped judging myself. I ignored the shame. I ignored the people’s voices in my head that told me ignorant things like “video game addiction isn’t a real addiction” and “get a plan and do something with your life” and similar things. I studied addiction like a college major. Eventually, after learning so much about what was going on inside myself, I hit a tipping point. Overcoming video game addiction was an educated decision. It was conviction, and for the first time I felt like I was facing it from a position of power. Knowledge really is power. I learned that one aspect of addiction is that it’s a coping mechanism, in every case, whatever the addiction is to. It’s always a coping mechanism, meaning I had to face whatever I was using games to cope with. For me, it was a cocktail of things that I really can’t get into right now, but I had to work through feelings of frustration and regret. It all revolved around my upbringing - church and school and then just feeling like I was lied to. “Shit didn’t turn out the way they said” kind of thing. Another important thing to note is the role dopamine plays in addiction. Most people know that dopamine is responsible for that feeling of reward and achievement. I forget who coined the term, but you can refer to it as “the pleasure of the feast.” However, dopamine is also responsible for your level of drive - it’s that feeling of desire, longing for something. This is “the pleasure of the hunt.” Simply put, addiction creates an imbalance here. It’s why you’re asking this question, it’s why you want to stop but you can’t. Drive is a chemical reaction. An external stimulus can fix this, a sacrifice or setting very high stakes. My marriage was at stake because of my addiction to video games; this didn’t fix my addiction necessarily, but it gave me perspective. Also, after studying addiction, I realized a bunch of other things at stake as well - most notably, TIME. What’s at stake for you? Or what can you give up that will hurt so much that your drive will reset and redirect itself? Edit: Sometimes the thing at stake isn’t anything tangible. I know of a woman who was addicted to both cocaine and heroin. She lost her opportunity for college education. She lost the love of her life. She lost her family. She lost her home. She lost almost everything. She was still an addict. Then, one time there was a drug-bust in her neighborhood and her supplier ended up in prison. To get drugs, she contemplated sleeping with her best friend’s boyfriend, who happened to be a dealer in another neighborhood. The fact that she seriously considered this was enough to make her realize she had a problem and she became serious about overcoming her addiction; she began to seek help. Dignity was at stake. Here’s my point: you’re on the right track by asking this question. The faster and more voraciously you learn about what you’re going through right now, the faster you’ll grow out of this. BTW, I still play video games.

Since I’m a Gamer (someone who plays video games on a daily basis), I probably wouldn’t be the best person to come to for this particular question. But I’ll take a stab at it. Boredom. If a game doesn’t interest you as much as it use to, eventually you’ll get the same feeling from your other games. And to make things harder as a gamer, you want to play other games but you don’t own them, you don’t have the money to get them, you know no one who owns who you could borrow it from, and you don’t have the means to play it even if you did buy it (Console or Computer Hardware). And though you have these other 100+ games, you jut feel “I don’t feel like play this or this or this or this” and get to a point where you’ll do something else to relieve the boredom. I was in that state for a couple months. I own close to 200 games, I’ve beaten barely 10 of them. I’ve played half of them, but the others I haven’t bothered with and sometimes question why I got them in the first place. But yeah, I hit that point and every game becomes uninteresting. There is no real cure for it. Even if the games are taken away, we’ll just crave it worse than a woman on her period who wants chocolate. And if we REALLY enjoy playing that game, even if we’ve beaten it a dozen times already, we’ll probably never let it go til something better comes along or boredom finally hits us. The big difference with Video Game Addiction vs Drugs - Games can’t kill you. And while many games are meant for shooting, fighting, whatever, there are others that have puzzles in them that will push the limits of our brains and make us think, make us learn something to beat the challenge. One game in particular - The Secret World (Now “Secret World Legends”) uses quests that require the player to LEARN real world stuff to beat the quest, like finding out when a pirate did this, or memorizing who signed the declaration of independence, or even who the secretary of state was in this date, and the information needed would be REAL, not made up. Hell, there was a quest I came across that required me to read the Bible, look for a certain verse, and them compare the verse shown in game with the real one & pick out what ISN’T suppose to be in the verse. And then there are games made by intellectual directors where you’ll come across words being used in the game, but you don’t know what they mean, and unless you find out what they mean, you’ll never understand what is going on in the game. So whats the only option? Look them up in the dictionary. So you’re not wasting your life away. People enjoy TV, Movies, Music, Art, Science/Math Lectures, whatever, but it is still a pleasure that people do & enjoy, and if video games are an addiction, then so is everything else. Another big thing that differs games from drugs - We’re not so addicted to it that we’ll suffer physical & mental anguish like we would from Alcohol & Cigarettes. I am a smoker as well. I am addicted to it. But the difference? I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING cause I know it will kill me someday, plus it’s an expensive that serves no other purpose than to make me sane, and I know that once I’m no longer addicted that I’ll be free from it & that much richer, THEN I’ll be able to get the things I want. What really keeps me from having & playing the games I want? Cigarettes. Cause if I had to choose what I feel like I need more than other, games are at the bottom & cigarettes are at the top. So I doubt you’ll want to subject kids to worse addiction than games just to get them to stop, but pretty much if you want them to stop, they’ll have to either get bored of playing them or satisfy something greater. That’s all I got.

I stopped my video game addiction about eight or nine years ago. When I did, I went about a year without playing games at all, then after awhile I played them in moderation. Today I own a PS4, PSVR, Xbox One X, a steering wheel, an Oculus Go, and a nice collection of games and I play all of them responsibly. First off, I will tell you the WRONG way to try and get rid of your addiction. That is to get rid of all your game systems and games and just say “no more”. I tried that and I got really depressed and bored, and a few weeks later I was gaming again. So what happened were two things. First, I had bought myself a big TV, a nice sound system, PS3, and a racing wheel and played Gran Turismo Five for several months staying up all night until I beat it. When it was over, I said to myself, “It can’t get any better than this” and I lost interest. Why? Because satisfaction is the opposite of addiction. If you are satisfied, you are done with something. Now, this first part I can’t possibly advise you on how to stage for yourself. For me it was incidental. I simply gamed until I was satisfied. The second thing that happened is I developed interest in other things, and for me it was language learning. This is an activity that I find deeply satisfying and something that I could do that shifted my attention off of gaming. So find something that is SATISFYING that you can put your attention on instead of gaming. Something beneficial. In other words, don’t break your addiction to gaming by taking up drinking or drugs. Lastly, an addiction is only an addiction if you do whatever it is to such an extent that you neglect important things, like work, sleep, people, taking care of yourself, etc. If you can maintain your responsibilities in life and can handle your problems, and still game a lot, then you are not addicted. So take care of yourself, and take care of others, and if you can game without staying up all night every night, then go ahead and do so.

The term addiction is often used loosely, and some people merely overdo things for awhile before moderating. However when it comes to video games and other internet activities, abuse or addiction is common. All addiction is chemical. Playing video games causes a release of chemicals in your brain which makes you feel good. There is nothing wrong with feeling good, but soon your brain has burned some deep neural pathways concerning the instantaneous reward you feel when playing video games. A pattern of thinking has developed that playing videos games is the best thing going. Other activities that you once enjoyed and activities necessary for you to be productive and happy in the long run have a hard time competing with the immediate rewards you rerceive from playing video games. Again, in many cases such a desire is merely a strong compulsion that can be controlled with some effort. In some cases, especially with people predisposed to addiction, it is a real addiction involving a seemingly uncontrollable obsession and compulsion. In my opinion, in the case of severe overuse or a real addiction, once you admit it, the best way to overcome it is to seek support and accountability. Find someone you trust who will understand, explain the situation, and talk with them regularly about how you are doing with video games. Just as importantly, find a range of other activities that make you feel good. Not just one, but a variety, so you don't merely replace one addiction with another. Preferably, some of these activities should include other people. Try some fun things, but also try doing some things on a regular basis that help other people, whether family, friends, or volunteering to help strangers. Scientific studies have revealed that helping other people is a strong motivator and also brings a strong feeling of reward and accomplishment. If some games are particularly tempting you may want to delete them temporarily or permanently, but merely deleting them won't solve the problem. Video games will always be there and you cannot hide from them forever. Better to deal with the root problem.

Here’s how I did it: First, find a piece of paper. On this piece of paper, write I WILL NOT PLAY VIDEO GAMES FOR THE NEXT 3 MONTHS(Insert date). This is called 90 day detox ,the most simple yet effective method to stop playing video games(or any addiction). Do not touch your video games for the next 3 months, that’s it. This will ONLY work if your brain is ready to take it there. You should be thinking how to stop this nuance from your life, not, I really love video games but since it’s bad I want to stop. In other words, your brain should kindle the light of stopping this addiction rather than a outside source. My guess is right now you are only playing video games as an addiction. You have grown up to the point where you don’t truly like video games any more. It’s pretty hard to describe this feeling, but this was the case with me and a couple of friends as well. By taking this detox, you will outgrow this hobby. For me, the 3rd week was when the urges came back. Although after a month, I didn’t think about it even once. Do not try to bilk this plan even once in the 3 months, or else you will have to start over. The reasoning for this technique is to get rid of the physical connections of attributing video games to happiness in your brain. Unfortunately this is only the first part. Notice how I told you get a sheet of paper, not a post it note. After writing the message said above, you are going to need to find and write other hobbies or ways to keep you occupied while you do this. The reason behind this is to suppress the urges to play video games. By filling in your schedule, there is a lower probability of you even creating the concussions thought of playing video games. THIS PART IS JUST AS IMPORTANT AS THE FIRST, or else you will get stuck in the loop. These are some of the tips based on my personal experience. REMEMBER, the number one thing in this process is YOU want to stop playing video games. Hope this helps!

I’m an avid gamer, it’s probably my favourite hobby, but there is no denying video games nowadays are designed to keep you playing for long periods of time. They are no longer products, they are services. When I was growing up games were often brutally difficult. I’d take a break from gaming on my own, after hitting a difficult section. Today almost all games are built around some form of progression. With experience levels, weapon unlocks/upgrades, achievements etc. There is a gratifying feedback loop which mimics how slot machines work. Some people are more prone to getting addicted to this than others. I’m one of those people. I used to have a ‘completionist’ mindset. I wanted to get all the achievements and rewards before I felt ‘done’ with a game. This turned playing games from a fun past-time into a job. I no longer played the game to have fun, I played to achieve some arbitrary goal. When you think about it, I was no longer a gamer, I was an employee working for the game systems. The only way to break out of this loop is to stop playing these types of games. Now I consciously avoid multiplayer games, MMOs etc. because I know I’ll get sucked in to the loop. Getting this kind of self-discipline did not happen overnight. The first thing I did was give up playing for a period of weeks. I started going to the gym because exercise is a great way to generate a natural buzz. I also set achievable goals in my life and started working towards them immediately. None of these things were easy, but over time they became habits. And that’s what it boils down to, change bad habits for good habits. Now when I play games, I play for me, not for someone elses notion of what ‘completing’ a game is. As Jim Rohn once said. Choose your pain. The pain of discipline or the pain of regret. I know what pain I’d rather choose.

The red flag in your question details for me is “my temperament becomes really hot if I don't play for 2–3 days. This actually suggested a physical withdrawal from your stimulus, and source of dopamine, your “drug of choice.” You may have an actual addiction. Please get assessed by a professional counselor. The other answers have good suggestions, like replacing gaming with more mindful activities like walking and meditation, setting a timer and gradually reducing the time you allow yourself to game. If you do have an addiction, these become attempts to control the addiction, not just healthier actions. If you try some of these suggestions and find they leave you irritable, restless, frustrated, angry, or deprived -absolutely seek professional help. Internet gaming disorder is not recognized by the DSM-V as an official addiction yet, but does list these criteria to determine the disorder: 1. Repetitive use of Internet-based games, often with other players, that leads to significant issues with functioning. Five of the following criteria must be met within one year: 2. Preoccupation or obsession with Internet games. 3. Withdrawal symptoms when not playing Internet games. 4. A build-up of tolerance–more time needs to be spent playing the games. 5. The person has tried to stop or curb playing Internet games, but has failed to do so. 6. The person has had a loss of interest in other life activities, such as hobbies. 7. A person has had continued overuse of Internet games even with the knowledge of how much they impact a person’s life. 8. The person lied to others about his or her Internet game usage. 9. The person uses Internet games to relieve anxiety or guilt–it’s a way to escape. I'm 10. The person has lost or put at risk and opportunity or relationship because of Internet games. Internet Gaming Disorder in DSM-5

I’m not really the best person for this answer but I’ll give my two cents. If you really believe you are addicted to video games, the best course of action would be to get some professional help from an addiction counselor or specialist.  Now for my two cents: When I was younger and more impressionable with less self control there was something I did that helped my self control in times in which I needed to focus on things other than video games. I removed the temptation entirely. Even when someone is addicted, you go through high points and low points. Immediately after your fix you don’t crave another cigarette for at least a few minutes (depending on how addicted you are it could be longer). The trouble really comes later on when it’s been days/weeks/months without the fix. For things like substance abuse this can be difficult as since these are consumables it’s already your habit to go and buy more so often times people buy the thing they’re addicted to without realizing it and then the temptation is in front of them again. Video games are a bit different. They’re tied to something (and something expensive to) whether it’s that PS4, Xbox, PC, or phone. What I did was completely remove the box (whatever it was) while I was in a moment of self control (usually right after I finished playing something) and gave it to a trusted person (started with a parent, then went to a friend) under the conditions that I not get it back until whatever I needed to accomplished was finished (usually a month or two but if you want to stop playing entirely it would be forever). Since the other person doesn’t care as much about video games as I do/did they wouldn’t see why it was a big deal and would easily keep it away from me. I suggest you do the same. If you’re a console or PC gamer, remove the box from your environment. Either give it away sell it or smash it to bits. If it’s a phone do the same. Since you need a phone in a modern day environment simply pick up a dumb phone from your provider (they’re dirt cheap now) and it will have everything you need without the ability to play games on it. I was diagnosed with video-game addiction (by a psychologist who specialized in addictions and anorexia). First, I did everything I could to moderate my time. That didn’t work. The problem is, the dopamine release from video-games will shut down the prefrontal cortex, responsible for higher thinking. So, even if I only spent 4 hours a day on gaming, the rest of the day would be spent in a fog. Moreover, it was extremely difficult to moderate the time I spent videogaming. Gaming addiction is all about the “5 more minutes.” I’ll just hand in this quest, then I’ll do that college assignment… I’ll just go back to town to log off, then I’ll get to sleep… I’ll just vendor all the junk in my inventory, then I’ll have that meal I’ve been putting off for 3 hours. Next thing you know, you didn’t sleep all night, and class or work starts in 40 minutes. It’s important to note that games these days are designed to be uncompletable… back when it was all on NES carts and CD ROMs, it took about four days to beat a game, maybe a week or two to dig through all the secrets… and you were done. With MMO’s, it’s all about being in first place. The moment you stop playing, someone else is clawing their way up to the top spot, your spot, so you start loosing just by not playing (guild rankings, PVP scores, collecting a set of “raid gear” for everyone in the guild… then you get new guild members, and you always want more guild members, they need raid gear). So, there is always more game to play: the players create an inexhaustible supply of “content” through competition. (Essentially, the business model of an MMO is to sell us, the players, to each other… we are not the consumers, we are the product). So, after about two years trying to moderate my time, I just quit (which is what my psychologist wanted from day one, but I was abstinent and he was very patient). Cold turkey. Period. It’s surprisingly easy to just… stop playing. And there really is nothing short of cold-turkey that works, (for an actual addict). Mind you, the only thing that gave me the motivation to quit was my pursuit of art. You really can’t do anything creative when your prefrontal cortex is a wad of cotton from dopamine, so it was either my artwork or the gaming. I went with art, and it probably saved my life. Don’t get me started on how bad my diabetic management got while I was gaming… lost vision in one eye before I wizened up.

Gaming is very addictive and people often find it hard to overcome this addiction. Here are a few tips to overcome your addiction:  1) Time yourself Record how much you play a particular game or games for a week. Not shocked by the number of hours you have been playing for? If you are a true video games addict, you could be playing for upwards of 24 hours a week. Think of it instead as a seventh of your week, three eight-hour sleeps (a generous amount of sleep a night by anyone’s measure), or 16 football matches. That should make you realise all the brilliant other things you could be doing with your time. 2) Read a walkthrough of the game This might sound counterintuitive, because you are reading something about the very game you are addicted to, but it will almost certainly ruin the game for you and kill the addiction. Once you have read a step-by-step guide on how to beat the game, the fun of discovering new things and finding what happens next is completely finished. The game should become much more boring, as it will no longer hold any surprises, and the game will be over for you. 3) Find some cheats In a similar vein to the last piece of advice, search out some of the best cheats a game has to offer. Be it flying a tank on Grand Theft Auto, or unlocking so-called “God modes” on James Bond Goldeneye, where you can summon any weapon in the game, cheating is guaranteed to break your addiction. It may take a while for the novelty of turning around the turret on your tank and taking off a little bit of time to get old, but once it has, the challenge of the game will be non-existent. And once there are no longer any challenges to a game, it will become boring faster than you can artificially boost your health. If you a feeling really advanced, use a memory editor like ArtMoney, which means that when your game is running, you can manipulate any numeric value in the game. Money, health and points will be at your mercy, rendering the game instantly less enjoyable. 4) Look around: are your friends real, or virtual? This is not to demean people who make friends playing video games online, or assume the character of the game they are playing so fully that their friends are virtual people. But it should not take long after asking this simple question to realise if you are a video game addict, the ratio of real to virtual friends will have slipped dramatically in favour of the latter. If you still do not feel like you are missing out, take roughly 22 minutes out of your gaming schedule to watch an episode of Friends. The next time you play a game, you should crave real human contact like never before. 5) Start playing games with your friends, not alone This may be tricky if having asked the question to number four, you find that the answer is you have no “real” friends left, but it is worth inviting friends round to play video games with you, or go to their house. Although you will want to play for as long as is possible, providing your friends are not addicted, there will come a point where they get bored, and they will force you to do something else. This should at least moderate the period of time you play for, and allow you to gradually reduce it over time. And if none of these five work, watch this rather zaney behavioural psychologist below.

I’m modifying an answer that I had to a similar question on how to uninstall video games to be productive. I used to be an avid gamer, and am still very passionate about gaming. I haven’t uninstalled any games on my computer (other than to free up hard drive space) What I think happened is that my priorities in life changed and I found more productive hobbies that naturally just took time away from gaming. I also started valuing my studies because I was interested in the topics I was studying in school I started bouldering, which is basically exercise disguised as a game, and many times where I would play games I find myself climbing. I started performing stand-up comedy. Writing and practicing comedy takes up a lot of the time where I would be playing games. Going to open mics is also another large chunk of my free time that i elect to use on something that isn’t gaming. I found a job, which naturally takes time away from gaming, because you have work obligations and less time in general. I became interested in my school subjects because I found things that I was passionate and interested in. If you don’t have these stimuli in your life and can’t find any, I can tell you some other reasons that i slowly just played fewer games. Talking to friends, I noticed that many people have so many exciting interests, hobbies and talents. At a certain point, I had nothing to show for other than “I play video games”. It was a slightly embarassing feeling, and I vainly wanted to show off how diverse I am. This vain part of me motivated me to become better at everything. At a certain point in time you want to find self-worth in your hobbies. Whether you validate yourself or others validate you, you’ll want to be someone you can be proud of. Now, in conversation, I can say all the things that I listed above, and even more things that I didn’t mention, AND that i play videogames. I accept that video games are a part of my life, but I have so many other aspects to me as well. You’ll eventually notice that the people who you play games with seem like they aren’t going anywhere, and if you keep playing games with them, you might end up going nowhere too. You’ll get the urge to branch out and do other things and have something to show for it. As I became less into videogames, I started talking to my friends that I played videogames with a lot less as well, just because there wasn’t as much in common anymore. It’s a bit circular. You choose to play less games, so you talk to the people that make you play games less, meaning you play less games as well. It loops in on itself. The people anchoring me to videogames were no longer doing that because I was talking to them less. As a result, one of the biggest motivations to play videogames disappeared. As I grew more distant from my friends that played videogames, I felt less pulled into videogames. A lot of videogames are social in nature, and people draw you in. Once you stop talking about it with these people, you’ll feel less of an urge to play. As you branch out and find more things that you enjoy, you’ll naturally spend less time on videogames. Gaming is addictive because it provides you with pleasure :) So a way to cut back is to think long and hard of what other activities could provide you with pleasure to the same extent or more. This is a very simplistic approach but it will help you. The important point here is to find other activities which would provide you pleasure but also purpose. You don’t have to cut gaming 100% but just replace some of the time you spend gaming with other hobbies (watching movies, playing with yourself or doing similar things which only provide you some kind of pleasure will not help..whatever you like doing should also provide you some positive reinforcement, should add value to your life). I would strongly suggest a physical activity (biking, running, boxing, swimming, etc.) because this will give you lots of pleasure AND it will be much better for your body and mind in the long run. In any case, just change something today. If you play 5–6–7–8 hours normally, play 1 hour less today and in that hour do something outside if you can or inside the house, but something constructive. I wish you strength, perseverance and inspiration to find other things good for you!

This is a challenge no less daunting than the other kinds of addiction. In my work with young people and even some older folks who have this affliction the consequences are very real and pervasive. The heightened increase in adrenaline and eye and hand coordinated aciivity provide an endorphin boost which is hard to let go of. This emotional and mental escape from real world drama or drudgery combined with the physiological effects is very real and draws one back over and over. Sense of time is lost, productivity and sense of responsibility and even fear of consequences go down. Seeing students who have failed an entire semester or even resulting in academic dismissal over this type of addiction is heart breaking or maddening to those who don't understand the power of this compulsion who think “just stop”. Much like any other addiction or compulsion the solution is at once simple and secondly neither easy or pleasant to hear. The only success I've had with addiction is complete abstinence. Know any “social” heroin users? No. Neither do I. When I'm in the grip of a true compulsive malady I just want a little “more”. Secret/not so secret: there's no such thing as a little more. If one is really not a true addict try some controlled playing. This might look like setting a time limit to play - say, for an hour. At the end of an hour - stop. Don't think about it anymore and go on to the next activity. A true addict probably can't do this. They may stop but can't stop “thinking” about returning to play or at the slightest provocation of a friend (who probably doesn't understand the corrosive and damaging results of addiction) saying “come on, just one more level or game”, immediately returns to playing without the ability to say “no, I'm going to go study/do something else”, Vows to quit or moderate play are repeatedly made and broken and before one realizes its become one of the primary focal points of everyday living all the time. I once had my husband say “are you even going to take a shower? Or change out of your pajamas?” And when I responded “in a second” and he pointed out it was 10pm (I had been playing since 9am) I realized how transfixed I'd become and how time, eating, sleeping, hygiene, nothing mattered when I was immersed in this other (and when in that state, I would have argued “better/more fun” world). So if one is a true video game addict it's not likely they can moderate or even play a little without getting sucked back in completely. There is, unfortunately, no middle of the road solution. Particularly for young people this is especially challenging because it's what their peers want to talk about and it can be a central point of socializing with friends. I wish you or anyone you know who might be afflicted the best. Take care and if we come across one another let's have a beverage or enjoy a nice walk outside (or anything productive) instead. :)

There are many underlying factors that push people into whatever things they may get into, but no matter what you wind up getting into, it's important to understand that you were an addict before you got into whatever you are addicted to… Your brain chemistry was already the way it is, and that's what people don't get. There are health issues with some things people get into, like physical dependence with drugs, weight issues, diabetes, heart disease, etc., with food, STDs with sex, and so on, but those are just side effects of what you're using/doing, not addiction itself… This is where many get things confused, especially with drug addiction, confusing the symptoms for the disorder. I find a group of like-minded people, supporting each other in their recovery, is extremely important in battling addiction. Gaming, like other behavioral addictions, is a habit of thought that is a stimulus/response cycle that happens beyond the awareness of the conscious mind. There are many habits of thought, mostly useful, and they are usually there because it is easier to have an automatic response to a stimulus than to have to think through a problem, if it is a problem you have faced many times before. Addictions are specific kinds of habits of thoughts where the person is using the habit to soothe themselves in a way that never addresses the underlying cause of the need to be soothed. This kind of habit of thought is not so useful because it perpetuates the need for the habit when, if you got rid of the underlying cause, you wouldn’t need the habit. The process for changing a habit of thought, is largely the same, no matter what kind of habit of thought you want to change. Usually people embark on this difficult work because they want to change a habit of thought that causes a behavioral pattern that makes them unhappy or is destructive or dysfunctional. Habits of thought that someone might want to change could be an annoying behavior, a mental health issue, an addiction, or any other habit. The good news is that this process works. The bad news is that this is a process that takes years and will require that people learn many new skills and practice them over and over until they become new habits of thought. Common habits of thought that people might want to change There are many habits of thought that people want to change. Some examples are: Addictions to substances or behaviors,Habitual, dysfunctional ways of interacting with other people, such as passive-aggressiveness, or other poor communication habits, orMental differences like depression, bipolar, schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, anorexia.The process outlined below can be used to change any habitual way you behave that you feel like you have no control over. Any behavior where it seems like something is making you behave this way that is beyond your control. Addiction Addictions are habits of thought that people often want to change. There are two criteria for an addiction. First, it is a thought habit where you recognize a problem and apply the same already-made solution to it without thinking. Second this thought pattern, even though it solves the problem, must do it in an inefficient or dysfunctional way. One criterion for it being dysfunctional is that the solution causes more problems in the long run than it solves. Most addictions solve the problem of emotional pain. However, instead of fixing the cause of the emotional pain, these solutions are like pain killers. They address the pain without addressing the cause of the pain. Once this becomes a habit, the brain is quite resistant to making changes in that habit of thought. In essence, the brain has learned that a solution works, and it never wants to have to think that pattern through again. Mental Differences Mental differences are dysfunctional mental habits, more commonly known as mental illness. Dysfunctional mental habits usually are the result of experiencing more shame for being unable to think and act the way you believe others expect you to act than you can handle. This results in behaviors that other people think are unusual and potentially harmful to yourself or others. Psychiatry has given these patterns of behavior many labels, such as bipolar disorder, depression, Schizophrenia, Psychopathy, Anorexia and many others. It is important for psychiatrists and insurers to label these behavior patterns because it helps them conduct research and get paid for “real” problems, not ordinary dysfunctions. The conscious mind doesn’t have as much control as it thinks it does It helps to understand the brain as made up of numerous different minds that don’t always agree with each other. Most people think they are in control of their thoughts. They experience themselves making decisions about what to think. This is how the conscious mind usually thinks. The conscious mind thinks it rules all the other minds, so it believes that if it understands a problem, all the other minds will follow its lead. However, the other minds (often referred to as the subconscious, but I prefer to call it the non-conscious so as to refer to all the ways our brains process problems that we are not aware of) are not so docile. Some of them hang onto their way very strongly, making it difficult and sometimes impossible for the conscious mind to lead all the interior ways of thinking to change their ways. The understanding that much of our thinking is automatic, not governed by the conscious mind, is helpful when figuring out how to change the way we think. The advantage of habits of thought Our brains evolved to be efficient problem solvers. One form of efficiency is that we learn to recognize different types of problems. One simple distinction is that there are problems like problems we have solved before and new problems. We have evolved to identify problems we have solved before so we can apply the solution that worked before as soon as possible, without spending much of our most precious resource, thinking, as possible. The disadvantage of habits of thought. Habits of thought can save us thinking time, but when a dysfunctional solution to a problem becomes a habit, it can cause a lot of problems. When a person is addicted, they will continue to go to a habitual solution to a problem, even if the conscious mind thinks it knows better. It seems to me the conscious mind is more influenced by the other parts of the mind than vice versa. The non-conscious mind has so much influence over the conscious mind that it can subvert the ability of the conscious mind to see things clearly. For example, many addicts are unwilling to even admit they are addicted until the evidence is far more convincing than we ordinarily require to come to know something. The difficulty in changing habits of thought It is very difficult to revamp your thinking habits. Habits, by definition, are built in to our brains so we don’t have to waste conscious time thinking about what to do in a given situation. People tend not even to be aware that they have thinking habits. The non-conscious mind responds to situations that it recognizes so quickly, that we do things without even realizing that we made a choice to do those things. We didn’t actually make a conscious choice. We made a non-conscious choice based on recognition of a type of problem that our brains solved long ago. Habits of thought developed over many years. They are a thought path that is followed over and over. Each time the path is followed, the connections between the neurons involved in that pattern of thought get stronger. Just as ancient footpaths eventually become superhighways to accommodate the traffic, neuronal connections of our thought habits become so strong that they are part of the infrastructure of our minds. We take them for granted. They are no longer a matter of discussion. An addiction is a thought superhighway that goes in circles, never getting you to the place you wanted to go. For most of the time we drive along these superhighway, we think we are getting somewhere other than back to the same place, over and over. How can we change habits of thought? The way to change habits of thought is by slowly working at it, step by step. We will have to uproot our thought “superhighways,” and then rebuild them so that they take us to where we want to go more directly. We will have to work at it over time — maybe not as much time as it took to build and reinforce the habit — but still, a long time. It is a matter of years of sustained effort. The importance of getting the conscious mind to recognize it has no control over habits of thought The effort to change addictions will not work as long as the conscious mind thinks it is in control. The conscious mind hates the thought of giving up the belief that it controls all of the mind. The conscious mind holds onto the idea that it is in control ferociously. It seems completely against our ordinary experience to believe we are not in control of our thoughts. Yet, if that is the truth, then using the conscious mind to guide the process of changing thought habits isn’t going to work. So, the first step is to recognize you (your conscious sense of self) have no control over this thought habit. This goes against pretty much everything you’ve probably ever been taught or experienced about your thinking. However, to actually change thought habits, you have to change the parts of the mind that are actually controlling the way you behave — the non-conscious mind. As long as the conscious mind thinks it is in control, you will try and try to fix your addiction and you will fail, over and over, which can make things worse. When the conscious mind can’t control your behavior, it thinks it is doing something wrong. It tries and fails, tries and fails. Eventually the conscious mind breaks, and blames itself for being unable to do this thing. The blame turns into shame, where the conscious mind starts beating on itself, thus making you feel like you are incapable and stupid. Thinking these kinds of thoughts about yourself over a long period of time can easily make you fall into a deep depression, where you are completely ashamed of yourself because your conscious mind can’t control the rest of your mind. The shame gets worse and worse the more your conscious mind fails, and eventually, you find yourself thinking you are a worthless human being who should die. How to get the conscious mind out of the way I’ve seen people get their conscious minds out of the way in several different ways. Some manage to argue themselves into this realization. They somehow find a way to convince it it has no control. Some are forced into it when the cognitive dissonance of constant failure gets so great, that the conscious mind breaks and is forced to give up. Yet others find ways to experience the quieting of the conscious mind, and eventually they learn to be able to quiet it almost at will. To convince your conscious mind that it that it has no control, you may try arguing yourself into the belief you have no control, but that may not work. That’s kind of like trying to learn how to play the piano by reading a book. You will understand the theory, but until you have the experience, you can’t really know what you are doing. Sometimes, people are forced into this realization by the crushing reality of their failure to fix themselves with the usual tools. You may have to be broken by this feeling of utter and complete failure in order to realize that your conscious mind can’t change you. If this happens, you may feel great relief for suddenly giving up the impossible burden. It may be such a strong sense of relief, that you will feel as if the proverbial weight has been lifted from your shoulders. If this happens, it will probably be quite recognizable because it will be such a clear feeling. I suppose this might happen without such a powerful sense of relief, but I doubt it. Another way to get your conscious mind out of the way is to work at it. There are any number of practices that will help you learn how to quiet the conscious mind, and these skills are going to be useful throughout the work to change your habits of thought. Meditation, yoga, exercise, activities that put you in a state of “flow” and other practices can help. However, if you work at it, I’m not sure you will get that sense of relief from your conscious mind suddenly giving up the fight. I think there is importance to the conscious mind breaking, because of the relief that can bring. Working with the non-conscious parts of your mind When you get your conscious mind out of the way, you can actually start working on changing the habits of thought, or a specific habit of thought where it will actually help — in the non-conscious mind. The non-conscious mind is taught by practice without expectation or practice without judgment. Judgment is the conscious mind creeping back in. It will try to do so all the time, so you have to learn to recognize when it appears. It appears whenever you think an idea that begins with “I should.” It appears whenever you think something is good or bad, a success or a failure. Practice simply means what it says, doing something over and over. You must practice doing things without expectation or judgment. Eventually, if you practice enough, this will become a new habit — doing things without expectation or judgment. There are many forms of this practice. Perhaps the most famous one is meditation. But any practice that quiets the conscious mind so you can do things simply to do them and not for a specific result will help. Play really helps, because play is just to play — unless you start judging yourself for winning or losing. It helps to play games which are purely fun; that can’t be won or lost. Other activities include exercise or volunteering. Exercise usually helps quiet the conscious mind because you get so focused on the physical, your conscious mind lets go for a while. Volunteering is work you do without compensation. The reward, if any, is in the doing of the work, or the response you get from the people you help, not getting paid in some concrete way. The point of all this practice is to gain experience with the feeling of being without your conscious mind always observing and/or judging. The more you experience this, the easier it will become to get to that experience. It will never be easy, but it will become easier after much practice. You can expect to practice this for the rest of your life. Finding triggers: identifying memories and events that cause automatic responses Once you understand this feeling of thinking without thoughts in words, you start to apply it to your life. First, you revisit your past, remembering it with this new habit of thought. Ironically, this is done deliberately, at the direction of your conscious mind. This is to change your attitude about the events of your past, and to reintegrate the historical revisionism into a different sense of self. You must investigate yourself in great detail in order to identify all the different kinds of ways that your past contributed to the subconscious problem and solution that you call an addiction. The point of this self-relearning is to get your subconscious mind to go back to each place or event that contributed to building your habit of thought, so you can prepare to consciously recognize when a current situation triggers that past, now automatic response. You will have to use your conscious mind to do this because it is the part of your mind that can analyze situations. You need to teach it to recognize when the subconscious mind is going on autopilot to trigger the addiction behavior. This is so that eventually, you’ll have an exhaustive list of triggers in your conscious memory that the conscious mind can recognize. When it recognizes a trigger, you will feel the urge to engage in your addictive behaviors. Usually, we just give into the feelings, which the subconscious mind feels and acts on. When people start identifying triggers, they often don’t do it until years after the fact. A therapist can help you go through your past with a fine tooth comb, looking for the first memory of when you felt a certain way. You then look for memories of the first time you responded to these feelings by fixing the feeling, not whatever caused the feeling. I think it is easier to do this work in a group of peers who have the same problems you do. Often, when other people share about their triggers, it reminds us of our own similar experiences. This is much more efficient than working with a therapist who doesn’t believe in sharing their own experience, as is typical. This is painstaking work that, like everything else in the process, takes years. However, with a lot of practice, you can learn to identify the triggers closer and closer in time to when they actually happen. The sooner you can recognize the trigger, the easier it is the use your conscious mind to divert that subconscious response into something else — something, preferably, that would solve the underlying problem, instead of solving the feeling. Developing alternative ways to respond to triggers Once you are able to recognize triggers in real time, you’ll need an arsenal of alternative responses that you can engage in at the direction of the conscious mind. There are two types of alternatives responses you will need to develop new skills to handle. The first set of skills you will need to develop are ways to intervene inside your head when you get triggered so that you do not resort to the automatic response of fixing the feeling caused by the problem, but not fixing the problem. The second is to identify the real problem causing the triggers, and learn how to solve that by fixing the problem instead of fixing the feelings only. These alternative responses will have to be figured out and learned. Again, this takes practice — lots of it. Stopping automatic responses to triggers When you find you are able to be aware of being triggered even as it happens, you can start doing something about that train of thought. I think the most effective way is not to try to fight them. Trying to oppose your thoughts directly often leads into the failure trap where you let your conscious mind try to fight and fail and feel shame. Instead of opposing your thoughts, you learn to acknowledge them, accept them, and then move on to another thought. Practice gently letting go of your self-shaming thoughts. I like to imagine that I write the thought on a leaf, and put it in the river of life that I am wading through. The leaf usually circles back to me (as thoughts will), but if I let it float away enough times, it will eventually actually float on down the river — leave my consciousness. I then have room to think other thoughts, instead of constantly recycling the thought that bothers me. Hopefully you can think other thoughts that you like thinking, but at the beginning of this process, it is most likely that the next thought is also one you want to gently let go of, and the next and the next. Eventually, with enough practice, you will be able to free up space in your consciousness to consider thoughts that cause less harm to you. This is a practice that takes years to become proficient at. Give yourself time to learn it. If you keep at it, you will eventually be able to identify your self-shaming thoughts as they happen and let them go before they do much damage. At first, you won’t identify them until hours or even days after they occur. You will have done a lot of self-shaming in the time between when you think the thought and you identify it as a trigger. But over time, the interval between the thought and identifying it as a trigger for self-shame will become shorter and shorter, and eventually, you’ll be able to work on letting it go before it has time to do much damage. There are many ways to practice letting go of thoughts. Meditation is a practice that teaches this skill. For some people, religious beliefs help them let go of thoughts. “Let go and let God” is the slogan that twelve steppers use for this skill. Anything that stops you from thinking in words and allows you to access nonverbal ways of thinking will help. Creative activities are pretty good, because once you get into the flow of creating, very few people are able to hold onto ruminative or shaming thoughts. Exercise is yet another way. Solving the actual problems Actual problems are the events that cause you to feel shame. Failing tests. Losing money. Not meeting the expectations of parents. The list of things that make us feel shame is probably endless. We learned to cover over the feeling of shame with compulsive behavior (often called addictions). Now we have to learn how to solve the problems that caused the feeling instead of just covering over the feeling. Probably the most important alternative you will learn is courage. The courage is to talk about the problem that is triggering your feelings. It takes courage to talk to parents about your perception of their expectations and to work with them to stop triggering you. It takes courage to admit to mistakes and ask for help in finding ways to fix the mistakes instead of drinking away your shame. Equally important are communication skills. If you have the courage to raise a subject you are afraid of, but you can’t get productive problem solving to start, your courage will be wasted. The communication skills are to help you negotiate a resolution to the problem more effectively when solving the problem requires cooperation with someone else — as most problems do. Other skills you will need are planning and surfing. Planning is something you can find out a lot about elsewhere. Surfing is about learning to improvise your way through life. The crucial part of it is to learn how to change directions instantly, when necessary; when blocked by an obstacle that is too strong to overcome. This is where you learn a kind of mental martial art. Instead of fighting things directly, you learn to use their energy to help you go where you want to go. You surf the waves and go where they send you for the most part, but also you are controlling how you surf the wave, always moving towards your goal. You will learn to not be attached to your planned path towards the goal, and eventually how not to be attached to the goal, itself. Ultimately, you will learn to appreciate the path or the surfing as fun in themselves, whether or not you get to where you thought you wanted to go. When this happens, you will enjoy much more of your life. You will completely give up beating yourself up for failure. There will be no failure, because you won’t care if you reach the goal. You’ll only care about working the waves. Installing more effective habits These new skills are nacent habits or proto-habits. Once you have developed new ways to respond to triggers, you need to reinforce these new proto-habits, and make them a part of your habitual thinking. You do this by practicing with people who you have hurt in your life back when your triggers led to addiction behavior instead of problem solving behavior. You must go through an exhaustive practice of identifying those you’ve hurt, figuring out how you’ve hurt them (where the problem solving went wrong) and then meeting with these people to tell them the mistakes you made and to let them know you are now working out a new way to cope with these problems, instead of using your addiction to cover the feelings. One way to practice your new habits is to visit people that you have harmed in the past, own up to the harm you caused, explain how and why you did it, and talk about how you will respond differently in the future. Meeting up with people from your past, often people you haven’t seen since you harmed them or they harmed you, gives you opportunities to practice courage and communication and creative problem solving. Finding your passion So you’ve given up conscious control. You’ve practiced not-judging and acceptance. You’ve identified your triggers. You’ve developed and practiced alternative responses to triggers that address the actual cause of the feeling instead of just making the feeling go away. You’ve developed new problem-solving habits and reinforced them. Now comes the fun part: figuring out who you really are when you aren’t being buffeted around by all those shoulds and oughts and self-judgments, good or bad. What is your passion? What gives you the most joy when you do it? Again, some introspection is involved, but actually, by this time, it may be obvious to you what you really get a kick out of now that you are living with self-acceptance instead of trying to do what you think others want you to do. If it isn’t obvious, keep on practicing accepting the guidance of your wants and desires until you find things you enjoy doing that actually solve your problems instead of covering over the feelings. When you get to figuring out your passion, you will no longer be living according to what you think others think you should do. Your thinking will no longer be clouded by that kind of thought interference. Now you can let yourself start to pay attention to your thoughts that are really yours. The ones you think naturally, before the shoulding interferes to blow those thoughts away. Once again, it can take years to become clear on your own thinking that you really get passionate about. This is when you can start working on your true goals. The goals you thought you had — the ones you think you have now — are probably not your true goals. They are goals to please others. Once you find your true goals, it will become much easier to work on them, because they are things you are passionate about and that you want to do.u Teaching others what you have learned We’re now at the final step in the process of putting your addiction into remission. This is where you take your passion and align it with activities that help others. If you are doing what you love to do, and helping others at the same time, who is going to complain? Who will be unhappy? You will, at this point, have created new, more effective habits of thinking that actually address your problems and let you do what you love to do while helping others. Of course, old habits are hard to break, and you will never really be able to let down your vigilance. The old habits are enshrined in your memory — built into your brain by your past years of thinking the same thoughts all the time, and strengthening the connections between the neurons involved in these old thoughts. Even though you’ve worked at reducing the strength of the memories and behaviors that became automatic responses in your addiction, and you’ve found a way to respond differently to situations that triggered your addiction, the old thought patterns are still there. They will always be there. You will always have to be mindful of that, and so, it will be helpful to continue to use this method, over and over, for the rest of your life. At this point, you will be ready to use your passion to help others. You will be able to teach others how to pursue their goals and teach them to the tools necessary to bring their thinking into alignment with their passion. This will be fulfilling in itself, and it will give you great joy because your passion is aligned with supporting others. This helps you strengthen your connection to others, so you no longer feel alone or isolated. Getting support to follow this process One of the easiest ways to do this work over and over for the rest of your life is to do it with others who are doing the same work. You can share ideas and experiences, and provide understanding when an old thought habit wins out over the new ones. Others can help you remind yourself that you are powerless over this — at least, your conscious mind is powerless. Your conscious mind is of great value when it comes to building new habits, but it has no power to give up old habits. That’s the work of your subconscious mind. The importance of patience As you can see, this is a long process. It takes a lot of practice to become proficient at these things. You have to give yourself time to learn. Impatience gets in your way, and is something you will need to learn to surf with. Acceptance of yourself as you are is a very important tool in this process. The more you learn self-acceptance, warts, depression, and all, the better you will be able to identify your passion and start to enjoy your life. Stories instead of debate You will come to stop judging yourself, and also stop judging others. You will come to realize that stories are what you want from others, not advice or argument. Right and wrong will become irrelevant issues. It will be moving from this point to the next point, accepting yourself and others however they make this movement, and working it into your path as best you can, without fighting yourself or anyone else. Being an adept Eventually, you will become adept at following your path and using that to help others, leading to greater connection and fulfillment and less worry about goals and success. Your life will be much easier because you no longer fight yourself to get anywhere. Instead, you go along with yourself. The work you need to do to achieve your goals stops being work and becomes play. Once you are playing your way through life, questions about motivating yourself will be irrelevant. You will always be motivated because everything you do will be aligned with what you want to do and who you want to be. Conclusion The process I have described will work. It will work for mental illnesses regardless of diagnosis. It will help with addictions of all kinds: addictions to substances or addictions to behaviors. It will work for any habit of thought that results in a behavior you want to change. These things are all changeable, but not by brute force. You start by coming to feel you can’t control yourself. Then, when you no longer believe you are in control, it becomes much easier to rebuild your way of thinking and make it more into what you want it to be. In the end, you find out what you love to do, and it is so much easier to keep on doing what you love to do than to be fighting yourself all the time. For more information about changing habits of thought, as related to specific addictions or mental health issues, or for information about how the brain structure works and how to work with the different types of thinking our brains are capable of and that contribute to habits of thought, read my blog: Change Habits of Thought.

Addiction is addiction is addiction. Be it alcohol, drugs, sex, gambling, or, yes, gaming. Each stimulates the hypothalmus - the brain’s pleasure center, which, builds tolerance to the stimulant, and we naturally seek to recreate that stimulation with more and more of the stimulant. The methods that have generally been working for all forms of addiction are the use of support groups through a structured program. The 12 steps is pretty standard. There are lots of meetings happening in every city and town - at most churches, many community centers, etc. There are lots of websites describing the 12 steps - these steps are basically the techniques of centering yourself so you can gain conscious control over your subconscious urges broken into 12 generalized steps to work through. Get to a meeting. Keep going to meetings. Work the program. If you work the program, the program works. Unlike alcohol, drugs and gambling, eliminating computers and internet access from one’s life entirely is close to impossible, depending on your profession. Therefore, you will always have triggers nearby. Therefore, you will have to always work the program. Always. If you claim that video game addiction is not the same as alcohol, drugs, gambling or sex, then you are at the first step - Denial. Stepping over that boulder starts the journey. Good luck.

Some of the earliest computer-based video games were just text (a story) with a branching storyline (very similar to the “choose your adventure” books that you can still run across from time to time), while others moved the pencil-and-paper games like D&D to a computer that could do the dice-rolling automatically.
